factoid: Hélène’s name day was celebrated with a small party of her own people at Prince Vasíli’s house.
Prince Vasíli’s wife said that the small party consisted of Hélène’s own people.
All friends and relations understood that Hélène’s fate would be decided that evening.
The visitors were seated for supper.
Princess Kuragina was sitting at the head of the table.
Princess Kuragina was a portly imposing woman who had once been handsome.
An old general and his wife sat on one side of Princess Kuragina.
Anna Pávlovna Scherer sat on the other side of Princess Kuragina.
The younger and less important guests sat at the other end of the table.
Members of the family sat at the other end of the table.
Pierre and Hélène sat side by side.
Prince Vasíli did not have supper.
Prince Vasíli walked around the table in a merry mood.
Prince Vasíli sat beside each guest in turn.
Prince Vasíli made careless remarks to each guest except Pierre and Hélène.
Prince Vasíli did not notice Pierre and Hélène.
Prince Vasíli enlivened the whole party.
Wax candles burned brightly.
Silver and crystal gleamed.
Ladies’ toilets gleamed.
Men’s epaulets were gold and silver.
Servants in scarlet liveries moved around the table.
Clatter of plates, knives, and glasses mingled with animated hum of conversations.
Old chamberlain assured an old baroness that he loved her passionately.
Old baroness laughed at the chamberlain’s confession.
Someone recounted the misfortunes of Mary Viktorovna at the other end of the table.
Prince Vasíli attracted everybody’s attention at the center of the table.
Prince Vasíli told the ladies about last Wednesday’s meeting of the Imperial Council.
Sergéy Kuzmích Vyazmítinov was the new military governor general of Petersburg.
Sergéy Kuzmích Vyazmítinov had received and read the rescript of Emperor Alexander.
The rescript was addressed from the army to Sergéy Kuzmích Vyazmítinov.
The rescript said that Emperor Alexander was receiving declarations of people’s loyalty from all sides.
The rescript said that the declaration from Petersburg gave Emperor Alexander particular pleasure.
The rescript said that Emperor Alexander was proud to be at the head of such a nation.
The rescript said that Emperor Alexander would endeavor to be worthy of the nation.
The rescript began with the words 'Sergéy Kuzmích, From all sides reports reach me.'
One of the ladies asked whether Sergéy Kuzmích had read beyond 'Sergéy Kuzmích'.
Prince Vasíli replied that Sergéy Kuzmích could not read beyond 'Sergéy Kuzmích'.
Prince Vasíli laughed while saying 'Sergéy Kuzmích... From all sides...'.
Sergéy Kuzmích could not read further in the rescript.
Sergéy Kuzmích began the rescript again and again.
Sergéy Kuzmích sobbed when he uttered 'Sergéy'.
Sergéy Kuzmích sobbed when he uttered 'Kuz-mí-ch'.
Sergéy Kuzmích sobbed when he uttered 'From all sides'.
Sergéy Kuzmích could not read further after 'From all sides'.
Sergéy Kuzmích used a handkerchief while reading.
Someone else was asked to read the rescript after Sergéy Kuzmích could not.
Someone laughed while repeating 'Kuzmích... From all sides... and then tears.'
Anna Pávlovna cried 'Don’t be unkind' from her end of the table.
Anna Pávlovna held up a threatening finger.
Anna Pávlovna said that Vyazmítinov was a worthy and excellent man.
